subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... Kyor?  That couldn t be anything but cure , so I wouldn t have trouble with it. ... That merger (pronouncing LOT like TRAP) is extraordinarily rare: it
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> - The CURE merge with THOUGHT/NORTH/FORCE would have to be done under
> #33. But could anyone in America read Key+Ye+Awe+Roe as the word "cure"

"Kyor?" That couldn't be anything but "cure", so I wouldn't have trouble
with it.

> - Allowing the TRAP-LOT merger looks like it will make #30 unintelligible.

That merger (pronouncing LOT like TRAP) is extraordinarily rare: it occurs
AFAIK only in Jamaican and very closely related accents.

> If we can use lexical groups to pre build a list of sample words for
> each QS letter for every accent

We don't need authoritative mergers for "every accent"; we can just
list sufficient words from each set, and then give generic advice
like "If you pronounce STRUT like FOOT, use Foot to write both."
(This is one I should have put in my "Lexical Sets in Groups" posting
but omitted; it applies to dialects in the North of England.)

Then we need no black/gray distinction: it just happens to be a
fact that nobody pronounces DRESS or CHOICE words like any of
the other sets.

--
Schlingt dreifach einen Kreis vom dies! John Cowan <cowan@...>
Schliesst euer Aug vor heiliger Schau, http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
Denn er genoss vom Honig-Tau,
Und trank die Milch vom Paradies. -- Coleridge (tr. Politzer)
